ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to read texts closely, how to read texts in historical context, how to read texts in concert with other texts, how to write creatively, how to craft a character.
I learned how to close read and delve deep into texts while being able connect what I read to my own personal experiences.

Because we were allowed to address some paper prompts creatively, I was able to develop my creative writing skills in a way that made me better understand the structure and language of the texts we read. I also learned to apply themes from DS literature texts to modern-day problems and ideas.
The Spring semester of DS Lit is so wonderful! Each book is excellent in its own right, and also builds on and challenges previous books on the syllabus.
Writing, speaking, and communicating analysis of literary works

I learned how to critically read works of literature and to discuss their themes, nuances, styles, and insights in a seminar setting at the college level, and I learned a lot about the process of bouncing ideas off of other students in discussion. Additionally, I learned how to write a literary analysis paper (as well as papers on more creative prompts) to clearly and effectively communicate my ideas about a text and how to connect the themes of one text with another.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths are the diversity of texts, weaknesses the high amount of pages to flip through. Also not very explicit about the movements of literature through history.

Overall, I think the spring semester DS literature track is really stellar, and I appreciate the actions the faculty have taken to diversify the curriculumbeing able to read texts such as A Raisin in the Sun and Omeros made the world of DS feel more expansive and more relatable to personal and modern-day experiences. One aspect for improvement is that I wish we could have spent some more time with certain texts. Some texts we only had about a day or so of class time to cover (as opposed to the usual two days), and not only did the lack of time make review for the exam more difficult, but it also made our engagement with the texts feel less fulfilling.
Strengths: Amazing syllabus, excellent lectures, section was consistently engaging and challenged me to think deeply and really dig into our readings.

Strengths: everything
Weaknesses: pace (but that is inevitable)

The strength of this course is its reading list: I firmly believe that everybody at Yale should read some if not all of the books on the reading list, and I certainly have discovered multiple classic novels and literature which will forever remain on my bookshelf. Additionally, the seminar format promoted discussion and various interpretations or focuses on different aspects of the text. However (and this is a general problem with all of DS), the extremely fast pace of DS prevents the sort of in-depth conversation and analysis of a text that I believe each text warrants, but this is a problem inherent with the nature of Directed Studies as a survey course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student simply because of the fantastic books and engaging lectures.
Yes! The curriculum this semester is full of wonderful texts, and Professor Handler Spitz is a warm, engaging instructor who teaches you so much both about the books and beyond.
Yes -- you should definitely take EHS for DS literature. She is the best and will teach you not only about the books you read, but how to appreciate them

Yes, and I especially recommend this course if taught by Professor Spitz. The reading list for spring semester DS literature is really stellar, and it explores a wide expanse of themes and perspectives. Professor Spitz was really welcoming and made our class feel like a family, encouraging us to share our personal experiences and connecting them to the literature that we read.
Yes definitely. It is a lot of reading but so worth it.
Yes, I think directed studies, and literature in particular, teaches students about themselves and the world.

I would definitely recommend this to any student interested in expanding their reading list and learning more about the major works of the Western tradition since the midieval era. However, I would stress that students should be very interested in the subject matter and have the time and commitment to make the most out of this class, as it is certainly not an easy courseload.
